content.body: So it seems like in Firefox, Selections aren't actually associated with a document, but rather with a window.
This actually makes sense.
yeeehaa
sorry, wrong window.
but somehow still appropriate :)

or Leeeroooy
What unsung genius decided that Python needed its own (broken and poorly-designed) package management system instead of integrating with the standard ones everyone uses?
sudo easy_install lxml has now not only failed repeatedly because non-Python dependencies weren't present, it then spent several minutes compiling something or other from source.
Now I just hope it works.
Wait a sec, does the DOM Range spec only compile using Ms2ger's forked version of Anolis?
Okay, I guess I'll ask him when he shows up.  I'll call it a day and start writing tests if I don't figure out how to get the spec to work.
can't go wrong writing tests ;-)
has just tripped over a part of the ISSUE-129 change proposal that has _so many_ errors he doesn't know what to do about it

(e.g. accordngy to the a11y tf, apparently aria-checked="true" must be set on any checkbox whose _default_ state is checked!)

wut
also they don't say it should be =true, they should say it should "match the state", without saying what that means
Does anyone else here only reliably notice it's their birthday when all the vBulletin forums they're a member of send them a happy birthday e-mail?
Because I just realized that's the case for me, which is sad.
Where are you seeing that, Hixie?
AryehGregor: Happy birthday
also according to this CP you are _not allowed_ to ever set aria-multiselectable="false" on a <select> even if the <select> has no multiple="" attribute
falls for AryehGregor's subtle ploy
TabAtkins: the trove of errors that is the "WAI-ARIA to HTML attribute mapping" table
:P
Hixie: Yeah, I'm looking at the input[type=checkbox] section of the table right now.
If I don't even remember it's my own birthday, I'm hardly going to fish for happy birthdays.  I was aware it was sometime around here, just didn't think about the exact day . . .
:P
pretty much every row of that table has at least one mistake
i'm not gonna list them all in the CCP, i'd be here forever
Hixie: Are you looking at http://www.paciellogroup.com/blog/misc/HTML5/aria-html5-proposal.html ?
Oh, I see, you're reading the lower table.
yeah, sorry for being unclear
Right, that lower table has several mistakes.
I'd offer to help, but I know absolutely nothing about ARIA.
Also, I have to go to bed and should stop procrastinating about that, so good night.
Hixie: you should reply that the change proposal is not accessible to people with brains
Btw, I'll go ahead and write the Issue-130 CP next week or so.
TabAtkins: cool. let me know if you need help, happy to help with that one.
2/win 3
No, I think it'd be pretty simple.  (1) Tables for layout are still bad for many reasons [list reasons].
note that "X is bad" is not necessarily sufficient to prove "it's better for X to be noncomforming"
True, but it may be sufficient for "This one 'improvement' isn't enough to justify making them conforming."
you'd have to translate the "X is bad" into what effects occur when X is conforming vs. nonconforming
presumably there is some marginal effect on willingness of authors to use X, at least for authors who are aware of and care about non-machine-checkable criteria
discovering rowspan="0" http://reference.sitepoint.com/html/th/rowspan
weird
"There is also a special value of "0", which should tell the browser to span the cell to the end of all rows inside the current rowgroup (that is, the thead, tfoot, or tbody)."

"Browser support for rowspan is generally good, with one exceptionâ€”rendering rowspan="0". Firefox and Opera are the only browsers tested that correctly span the cell to which this attribute is applied across all subsequent rows; the other browsers tested render the cell in the first row only."

TabAtkins: the table thing has at least two other pretty important points to include: first, that no version of HTML has ever allowed layout tables in the first place, so it's not like we're making old valid code invalid, and second, that making tables-for-layout ok would undo literally a decade or more of advocacy, which would seriously harm the credibility of the effort with early adopters and advocates
Hixie: the TF hasn't yet quite figured out what problem it is trying to solve, but it is trying to come up with a list of use cases to consider
GPH-Zeke: the validator has been updated piecemeal and is always at or near the tip of the tree
MikeSmith: window.parseHtmlDocument(inputText, documentObject, callbackWhenDone, nullPlaceHolderForErrorCallback);
hsivonen: thanks
hsivonen: K, thanks.
hsivonen: interesting
hsivonen: is there a draft of those use cases anywhere?
hsivonen: I've checked in patches for all the remaining validator bugs/enhancements I had open for now
if you could please redeploy today or soon, I will also redeploy the HTML5 backends on all the W3C validator hosts so we can have those synced up
MikeSmith: I'll redeploy today
cool
thanks
Hixie: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-xml/2010Dec/0064.html
I've been skimming public-html-xml archives today
it is hard to tell what the goal is there
as far as i can tell, all the use cases listed in that e-mail have well-understood, well-established, and already-deployed solutions

1: what normal describes (there's no namespace problem); 2: use an XML parser (browsers have been doing this for years); 3: as he says, XHTML, or as Atom does, a CDATA block; 4: <script> is designed for this purpose now; 5: just a combination of 3 and 4, nothing special beyond that is needed.

case 2 was explained further in http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-xml/2011Jan/0045.html; the solution is to transform the content into HTML using an XML parser, and HTML serialiser, and some logic
hsivonen: if you think the polyglot spec should have dire warnings, I suggest filing a bug to that effect (re http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-xml/2011Jan/0138.html )
only 14 bits remaining to write on http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Change_Proposal_for_ISSUE-129 ... in case anyone is bored and looking for something to do :-D

ok
did they edit .htaccess, or one of your PHP or python scripts?
PHP
but I have not checked everything yet
I have changed my dreamhost account and database password
Do you use any non-custom stuff on it? I remember WP having some bug that was exploited like thatâ€¦
WP seriously needs an action for "Delete this post, its author and all other posts from the same author" in the "Posts" admin view
yes, in various places I do
annevk: I would suspect them more than any password.
hsivonen, it's easier if you delete the author instead, and then you take out all the posts along with them
gsnedders, but the hack was crafted specifically for my site
Lachy: I mean the Posts view seriously needs a shortcut for that
annevk: In what way?
hsivonen, yeah, I know
Lachy: I think copying and pasting usernames between the two views isn't a useful exercise
no, it's annoying, but it's the most effective way I found to do it, given the limitations
gsnedders, they figured out how my site was structured, modified one file and added another one to aid and that was it

but buying a separate VM for Bugzilla and test cases seems like an overkill
s/Python/PHP/
wonders what's wrong with having Perl on one's server
Philip`: I see security patches for the Perl packages too often
oh I can still check modified dates
likes that Perl has taint mode, since that makes things feel a bit safer
five fricking days
annevk: did you already end up in some kind of badware filter?

annevk: how? did Google flag your site as dangerous?

and when I ran that I got results for Viagra

but they have fiddled with my .htaccess as well
but I can help try to figure out why it's happening
but they made a few mistakes which screwed up the encoding and made the 2011 archive stop working
that is only why I noticed that

jgraham, there's nothing to stop Python repos from at least integrating sanely with the native package management system.  Like automatically installing dependencies from the local package manager.  Or, I don't know, shipping binaries instead of just source code.
Anyway, timescales are irrelevant.  You can have an APT repository that's updated every two minutes.
I didn't say it had to be the distro's repo, just that it should use the same system, or one with comparably many features.
grumbles
You are proposing that PyPI provides its own repositories for linux systems?
That seems complex and not that useful
Why not?  Plenty of places do it.  Opera, for instance.
Just write something that will convert eggs into .deb's.
And allow authors to specify per-distro dependencies.

Ms2ger, so do you have instructions somewhere for how to compile your version of Anolis, or do I just have to submit patches blindly and hope they work?  Because there's a bunch more stuff I'm slated to do with Selections.
.deb files aren't especially useful for distros that don't use .deb files
Authors don't want to specify per-distro anything since they are likely not using linux at all
So also have something that converts them to RPM files.
Some don't use RPM files either
But mostly you don't want to use system-wide packages
easy_install doesn't use system-wide packages?
Philip`, they can suffer for their obstinacy.
The only packages I would consider installing system-wide are things like NumPy
AryehGregor: It does, by default
That is a bug
I see.
Like I said the One True Way is to use Virtualenv + pip
I stand by my position: this is a mess.
It's not great, but no worse than ruby + gems or java + (whatever it is they use)
maven?
AryehGregor: I don't want to suffer :-(
Or PHP + PEAR, or Perl + CPAN, I guess.
Philip`, then use a distro that doesn't behave radically differently from the distros normal people use.
Some relatively normal people use Gentoo/Arch/Pardus/etc
I dispute that characterization.
Really normal people just use Windows, so it's only a difference of degree
installs most Perl/Python packages on Gentoo via the standard Portage package system, since it's got most of the common ones that he wants
should have checked that before using easy_install on all of these
Is there a way to uninstall stuff installed via easy_install?
Wow, they even have html5lib.
finds docs, although it has no man page . . .
maybe uneasy_install ;)
AryehGregor: Not really
Clearly they couldn't be missing a fundamental feature like that, so just run easy_install --help and look for the uninstall option, which is, uh, ... not there?
In general the install script can do anything so it's not really trivial to implement
I did easy_install -mxN followed by rm -rf on the .egg directory it mentioned when I did that, will that horribly break everything?
Yeah, I actually remember that this is what I was told one time before when I used easy_install.
No.
It shouldn't horribly break everything
pip has uninstall

I guess I must have optimistically hoped that whoever was responsible for that decision must have been clubbed to death by an angry mob and replaced by someone not entirely incompetent in the interim.
Did I mention that virtualenv + pip is the way forward?
Yes, but the stuff I was pointed to by docs said easy_install.
AryehGregor: That is not quite unlike the truth
Python library install scripts surely can't be more complex than arbitrary Linux package install scripts, and Linux package managers provide uninstall, so that doesn't seem like a very good excuse
Like this: http://code.google.com/p/html5lib/wiki/UserDocumentation
Yeah, presumably you just have to write a matching uninstall script.
what Philip` said
AryehGregor: pip will install anything easy)install will install
I guess the easy_ part means "simple minded"
a package-management system that doesn't provide an uninstall mechanism is nuts
(they didn't club him to death, but they did treat him as damage to be routed around)
has never installed html5lib, he always just downloads from SVN/Hg and points PYTHONPATH at it, because that seems the least confusing option
(by writing better replacements for his tools)
generally clones from hg and does python setup.py develop inside a virtualenv
What exactly is virtualenv?
It is a way of creating a python environment in a given directory
usually the root directory of whatever you are writing
so if you are creating a spam project, you do
vitrualenv spam
and it wil create ./spam
then cd spam; source bin/activate
and all python packages you install whilst the environment is activated will go in the spam directory
Does anyone know how to get blame info for Mozilla stuff from the pre-hg era?  I can't quickly find instructions on Google.
and that will be first on your python path, so everything will be loaded from there too
(--no-site-packages means that it will never look outside the virtualenv)
http://iamzed.com/2009/05/07/a-primer-on-virtualenv/

then select file then select CVS Blame

http://mxr.mozilla.org/mozilla/source/layout/generic/nsSelection.cpp

yeah, references is another new feature

But I think it should be OK to provide a URL

you mean to override?

No, I mean that you have to provide a json file with paths to the differnt xspec-xrefs
instead you should be able to provide URLs to the different xspec-xrefs
(or rather to the json files that provide them)
I see... can't pimpmyspec simply keep them around?
Not really. There is no unique name or anything
shortname of specs ought to be unique
Yeah, but afaict nothing enforces that in the current design
and you need to deal with updates and such
if all specs are generated through pimpmyspec.net you should always have uptodate info :)
Anyway, this is all possible but will probably require some minor backend changes
I think I'm writing too many tests.

That's possible

What's the JavaScript way to check if an element is in an array?  .indexOf != -1, no cute "in" stuff like in Python?
How well supported is indexOf?
I don't know.  What's the alternative?
for (var i = 0; i < haystack.length; ++i) { if (haystack[i] === needle) { win(); } } lose()
http://www.w3schools.com/jsref/jsref_obj_array.asp doesn't mention Array.indexOf
so I guess it didn't exist when they wrote that site in the 90s
http://w3fools.com/ :))
nimbupani, nice
nimbupani, should I contact them about the inaccuracies I've found in their corrections?  :)
There are actually quite a lot.
Although not nearly as bad as w3schools.
them = me paul_irish and a bunch of others who are also lurking here
so please say it here
so I can correct em on the fly :)
Ah.

"Again, frames are considered among the very worst of practices in modern Web development. In fact, they are considered so bad, they have been removed completely from the HTML5 spec."  There are still implementation conformance requirements for <frame> in HTML5.

'"Correctly" does not mean "try to guess and maybe get it right some of the time", which is what actually happens, usually in different ways between different browsers.'  The last part is wrong in common cases (end-tag substitution is often pretty uniform), and will be totally wrong once all browsers are using HTML5 parsers.
"In HTML-dialect HTML5, boolean attributes like hidden do not have a value."  They do have a value.  The value is just irrelevant to how the attribute is processed.

"Furthermore,
isn't semantic and probably should not be mentioned at all."
is semantic in some cases, such as poems or addresses.
"This is wrong. All of these elements were deprecated in HTML4."  But <i>, <b>, and <small> are no longer deprecated as of HTML5.
"This code is wrong. Non-block-level elements (such as <input> or CDATA) are not valid directly inside <form> tags until HTML5."  Thus it's right, as of HTML5 . . .
got it.

"This is false. URL encodings are not ISO-8859-1. RFC 3986 is the standard defining URL encoding, and specifies that textual characters should, in fact, be mapped to UTF-8 octets."  But in practice they're often generated and processed using various random non-UTF-8 encodings (AFAIK).
"XHTML has been discontinued" - not really; XHTML5 is still being developed
maybe the good sentence is "XHTML 2.0 has been discontinued"
That would be an irrelevant sentence
AryehGregor, actually no
No to which?
All of them ;)
AryehGregor, only the query string can end up as non-UTF-8
Well, that's part of the URL, isn't it?
Philip`: would you prefer? "The work on XHTML 2.0 has been discontinued and published as a W3C note. XHTML5 is the new XML serialization of HTML5"
AryehGregor, yes, but the path is always encoded as UTF-8
Well, okay.
The point stands.
I believe the point was that any reference to XHTML2 is irrelevant
AryehGregor, well, it's not random and it's also not various
"Oh, and by the way, user-agent sniffing is a very bad thing, because is easily spoofable" - that's not why it's a very bad thing
AryehGregor, would be a pretty poor substitute :)
"The language was eventually standardized under the creative name ECMAScript by the EMCA international standards organization" Typo, EMCA instead of ECMA.
hehe
annevk, all right, all right, but the original was still wrong.

karlcow: i think *they* need a way to collect issues :)
OH SHIT AryehGregor
damn it
hehe
You gotta love irc :)

"Furthermore, addressing has nothing to do with TCP. It happens on the OSI network layer; this information is very specific to IPv4 and is going to be increasingly obsolete as time goes on."  To be extremely pedantic, TCP does actually know about IP addresses, in that it uses the source and destination IP addresses to compute the checksum it puts in the segment header.
AryehGregor:  our audience is mostly people who think w3c and w3schools are the same :/

"Actually, correct HTML is
, correct XHTML is
"
is correct HTML5, as well as
.

yes agreed.
W3Schools says "TCP/IP" anyway, not "TCP"
so complaining about TCP is irrelevant
"We think the resources we've recommended are superior for a variety of reasons." -- either say why or omit "variety of reasons"
Okay, that's enough nitpicking.
Back to work.
Yay tests!
Also addressing doesn't just happen on the network layer, it happens all over the place (like in DNS and FTP)
Thanks AryehGregor appreciate it quite a bit.

better that people use <b> and <i> than something uninformed
<b> is certainly better than <span style="font-weight:bold;">
And in many cases better than <strong>.

my main concern is that with the proliferation of mobile devices in the next few years, the requirement to code a site out on a platform that will generate different markup based on the device, will be necessary.  However, if there was more structure to the html, it'd be possible for UAs to display, at the request of the site with a meta tag, a different version, based on the semantic markup

i made "root element" mean two things so that when i defined things in terms of the root element, it would just work for fragments without having to explicitly mention fragments (which would make the spec even more verbose otherwise)
this would allow us to code a site once, and possible provide different stylesheets, and improve the mobile browsing experience drastically
this way it's complicated for people who are able to understand why it's complicated and it doesn't complicate the spec for people who don't care about fragments
